titleStmt.title: A copie of a letter of the taking of Leicester on Wednesday the 18th. of June, 1645. With the copie of the articles, and the manner of storming it the day before: a list of what was taken in Leicester, 14 peeces of ordnance, 30 colours, 200 armes, 500 horse, 50 barrels of gunpowder. And all their ammunition and provisions, of bagge and baggage. The Lord of Loughborough to goe to Ashby de la Zouch, and the rest of the officers and souldiers to Lichfield. The severall marches of the King since hee was routed, and his numbers, and how pursued by Sir John Gell, and 200 horse by him taken from the King. Brought from the army, and commanded to be forthwith printed and published.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: An exact and perfect Relation of the manner of taking of LEICESTER, with the Treity and all the particulers concerning the ≈øame, certified by a Letter from an eminent per≈øon (there) of the Army.
div.p: VPon the routing of the Kings Army, Sir John Gell gathered together all the forces of Derbi≈øhire, Notingham≈øhire, and the adjacent parts that hee could, and on Munday the 16. th of Iune, 1646. They met with ≈øome of the Kings hor≈øe and tooke 200. And another party met with ≈øome of the Newarkers, and fell upon them, and routed them, tooke 60 Hor≈øes, 42 Pri≈øoners, and 80 Armes. The Scots wee heare are at Che≈øterfield, and Sir William Brereton at Stafford marching this way.

On the ≈øaid Munday Iune the 16. Sir Thomas Fairfax lay before Leice≈øter and ≈øent in a Summons to the Towne, to require the Governour to ≈øurrender it to him for the u≈øe of the Parliament; and putting it to them to con≈øider how the King was routed, and ≈øhewing them what u≈øe they might make of that Clemency, with divers other very gallant expre≈ø≈øions to the ≈øummons, to adverti≈øe them how much better it was for them to ≈øurrender then to force him to take it by ≈øtorming.

To this ≈øummons the Enemy ≈øent a negative An≈øwer, po≈øitively this, that they would not ≈øurrender it; whereupon Sir Thomas Fairfax called a Councell of Warre to con≈øult about the Storming of it, which was ≈øoon concluded on; that they ≈øhould prepare all things in readine≈ø≈øe to round it the next day: which was done with all expedition not loo≈øing any time.

So they fell pre≈øently to rai≈øing of Batteries, and doing all things that were nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øtorming thereof according as they had appointed, and continued providing every thing that had appointed, and continued providing every thing that was requi≈øite for the doing thereof, to be in a readine≈ø≈øe to batter it the next day, and ≈øent into the Country thereabouts for ≈øuch helpes as were nece≈ø≈øary for the worke, which went on with great ≈øpeed both night and day; ≈øo de≈øirous wee are to have a ≈øpeedy end of the worke that there may be an end of the≈øe warres if po≈ø≈øible.

On Tue≈øday the 17. th of June, wee drew downe our Ordnance and playd with our Pieces again≈øt the Towne, we ≈øtormed it playing with our Ordnance very hot on the Newarke ≈øide, which we conceived was their greate≈øt
≈øtrength? And in ≈øhort time we made a breach in their workes, which ≈øtrucke ≈øuch a terror into the hearts of the Enemy, that the Governour ≈øent to us to de≈øtre a Parley, and offered to ≈øurrender upon very faire termes; as upon capitulation ≈øhould be agreed upon.

To this reque≈øt (Sir Thomas Fairfax being willing to ≈øave the ≈øpilling of innocent blood as much as may be) he a≈ø≈øented: and promi≈øed ≈øpeedily to ≈øend in Commi≈ø≈øioners for the treaty, and called a Councell of warre and it was agreed that Collonel Pickering, and Collonel Rein≈øoorough ≈øhould go into Leicester to treat with the Governour about the ≈øurrendring the ≈øaid Garri≈øon to Sir Thomas Fairfax. And accordingly a ≈øafe conduct was de≈øired for them, which being ≈øent they went to Capitulate with the Governour about the ≈øurrender thereof.

In the meane time Sit Thomas Farfax was not idle, nor did he loo≈øe any time; but went on providing and furni≈øhing him≈øelfe with Pittars, Carts, Hay, Granadoes, Ladders, and all other things nece≈ø≈øary for ≈øtorming; re≈øolving to fall on at their returne, in ca≈øe that they ≈øhould not agree, not knowing how things might fall out, during which time there was both great paynes and care taken by all in their places for the going on in the ≈øayd worke.

In the meane time we had Intelligence that the King was on Munday the 16 of Iune at Sheffield; that he came from A≈øh by de la zouch thether with about 2000 hor≈øe, or more, the day before, viz. Sunday night, and matched that morning (viz. Munday morning) to a
Randez vou≈øe neere Dudley Ca≈øtle, where with the Lichfield, and Dudley hor≈øe, and others that come in to their Randez-vou≈øes, the King had above 3000 hor≈øe as is conjectured by the Country people which ≈øaw them.

About 11 of the clocke on Munday morning, they marched from thence to Sturbridge, where he had ≈øome more Hor≈øe came in, ≈øo that in all it is conceived that hee is nigh 4000. Divers of which hee hath been faine to rectuite with fre≈øh Armes from Lichfield, Dudley, and other Garri≈øons the reabouts.

The King it is believed will for Worce≈øter, and there joyne with what Forces Gerhard can releeve him with, and ≈øome more Forces that hee lookes for out of the We≈øt; but Collonel Gerhard hath met with a rout al≈øo in Shrop≈øhire, where he lo≈øt almo≈øt 400 men, by fighting with the Countrey forces, and the Governour of Worce≈øter was killed, and divers other Officers of note were ≈øl ‚Ä¢ ine, and taken.

All the re≈øt of that day, viz. Munday the 16 of Iune, our Commi≈ø≈øioners were in Capitulation with the Enemy in Leice≈øter, and the Army went on preparing for a Storme, having no An≈øwer that night, and looking for their returne the next Morning very earely, were re≈øolved to fall on if they had not agreed with the Enemy.

On Wed ‚Ä¢ e≈øday Iune the 18. about two of the clock, the Commi≈ø≈øioners, viz. Collonel Reinsborough, and Collonel Pi ‚Ä¢ kering, returned with a Conclu≈øion of the delivery of it up upon the≈øe Articles following.

div.p: With the≈øe Articles the Commi≈ø≈øioners returned to Sir Thomas Fairfax, certifying further how ioyfull that poore Towne of Leice≈øter was at the hearing of the ≈øaid agreement, and that they ≈øhould be rid of the C ‚Ä¢ valiers.

Thus you ≈øee the Lord doth wonderfully for us, above the reach of m ‚Ä¢ ns wi≈ødome. Truly we cannot but much admire the goodne≈ø≈øe of Almighty God to us, in doing ≈øo great things for us, we cannot a≈øcribe it to any but to the hand of God Almighty, who is the Lord of Ho≈øts.
